description: Inherited from Middle English bordure, from Old French bordeure, of Germanic origin, from Frankish *bord, equivalent to modern French bord (“a border”) + -er.
Akin to Middle High German borte (“border, trim”), German Borte (“ribbon, trimming”). Doublet of bordure. More at board.

entries.meaning: The line or frontier area separating political or geographical regions.
examples: The Ministry of Defence said on Wednesday the men had been killed on Tuesday in the Nahr-e Saraj district of Helmand province, on the border of Kandahar just north of the provincial capital Lashkar Gah.

entries.meaning: A decorative strip around the edge of something.
examples: There's a nice frilly border around the picture frame.
a solid border around a table of figures

entries.meaning: A strip of ground in which ornamental plants are grown.

(Britain, uncountable) border morris or border dancing; a vigorous style of traditional English dance originating from villages along the border between England and Wales, performed by a team of dancers usually with their faces disguised with black makeup.
(computing) A string that is both a prefix and a suffix of another particular string.

verbs.description: border (third-person singular simple present borders, present participle bordering, simple past and past participle bordered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put a border on something.
(transitive) To form a border around; to bound.
(transitive) To lie on, or adjacent to, a border of.
examples: Denmark borders Germany to the south.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To touch at a border (with on, upon, or with).
(intransitive) To approach; to come near to; to verge (with on or upon).
examples: Wit which borders upon profaneness  […] deserves to be branded as folly.
